messageBody:
Hiya, this isn't strickly a JUnit question, but more a general java
question, mixed with JUnit.

I have a piece of code (currently in a JSPTag) which runs a piece of code
based on the logical outcome of a series of boolean expressions (rules).

The code looks something like:

// Check currentRec status against props
if (
(props.isSomeFeature() && !props.isSomeOther() &&
!currentRec.isBilled()) ||
(another rule...) ||
(another rule...)
)
{
....
}

The rules all boil down to checking wheather the current record should be
editable, so I was thinking of moving it all into say
currentRec.isEditable() to make it cleaner.

But, I still don't really like the idea of the big messy if statement,
whats the best way to break it down in a way that is both easily
maintainable, readable, and testable?

I was thinking:

public boolean isEditable() {
return (checkRule1() && checkRule2() && checkRule3());
}

But then I was thinking that these sets of business rules, look very
similiar to a test case, a series of short routines, that look at some
data, and ultimately return a pass/fail response. Whats the best way to
handle this? I would also invisage having tests for each rule,
testCheckRule1, testCheckRule2 etc. etc.

Are there any existing patterns/frameworks for implementing rule based
logic cleanly?

Mark
